page.title: 19LANGUAGE
page.content: Although the very distinct north-east language (the Doric as it was called) has largely died out, a certain amount of modified Doric is still spoken, especially among the older generation. Now the language tends to be more of a compromise with Scottish idiom spoken using English words & given Scottish endings. Several of the older Scottish words survive, especially where there is no exact English equivalent. Some of these words had their origans in the time of Mary Queen of Scots and are influenced by the Auld Alliance: eg ashet (assiette) - a large oval meat dish; and rooser (rosier) - a watering can. Other words specifically used with traditional methods of work survive, eg graipe - a wide shorter -handled farm fork used for digging. Besom -a heather tufted broom now seen only as a fire-beater in the forest.
